Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
08/10/2019. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract
and Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules
are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4111 Job description.
An institution shall provide a job description for each staff
position that identifies rules, required qualifications, and lines of
authority.
Five out of seventeen employee records employed less than one year did not
contain a job description.
Repeat citation from 07/06/2018 renewal inspection report
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(b) A true copy of verification of education from an accredited
college or university where minimum education requirements
are specified by rule.
One out of seventeen applicable employee records employed less than one year did
not contain a true copy of verification of education. It is noted that a copy of the
degree was present in the file.
Repeat citation from 07/06/2018 renewal inspection report
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
1

Two out of seventeen employee records employed less than one year did not
contain three dated references. The files contained only two references each.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(g) If the employee has criminal convictions, the institution
shall complete a written evaluation of the convictions that
addresses the nature of the conviction, the length of time since
the conviction, and the relationship of the conviction to regulated
activity for the purpose of determining suitability for employment
in the institution.
One out of seventeen employee records employed less than one year did not
contain a written evaluation of convictions.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
2

Ten out of 13 applicable employee records reviewed did not meet the requirements
of this rule. Eight records did not contain an annually updated central registry check,
one was late in update by one month, and one contained a registry check completed
beyond thirty days of hire.
Repeat citation from 07/06/2018 renewal inspection report
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
Ten out of 13 employee records reviewed did not meet the requirements of this rule.
Eight records did not contain an annually updated TB test, one was late in update by
one month, and one contained an initial TB test that was completed one day after
their date of hire.
Repeat citation from 07/06/2018 renewal inspection report
R 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
(2) An institution shall have the following documentation of an
admission physical examination for each resident, unless an
earlier examination is medically indicated:
(b) For a resident 3 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 1 year prior
to admission or a new physical examination shall be
completed within 30 calendar days after admission.
3

Three out of eight case records reviewed contained a late physical examination.
The first resident was admitted on 03/13/2019, whereas the examination was
completed on 05/01/2019. The second resident was admitted on 04/15/2019,
whereas the examination was completed on 05/22/2019. The third resident was
admitted on 02/20/2019, whereas the examination was completed on 05/08/2019.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(c) A brief description of the resident's preparation for
placement and general physical and emotional state at the time
of admission.
One out of eight case records reviewed did not contain the initial documentation
form that would have captured the resident’s brief description of their preparation for
placement and general physical and emotional state at the time of admission.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(g) Authorization to provide medical, dental, and surgical
care and treatment as provided in section 14 a (1), (2), and (3)
of 1973 PA 116, MCL 722.124a.
One out of eight case records reviewed did not contain medical authorization being
present in the file. It is noted that the facility requested the information from the
referring case manager.
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the new
location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the services
provided while in residence, including medical and dental
services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to be
met.
4

(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan recommendations,
including medical and dental follow up that is needed, have
been reviewed with the resident and with the parent and with
the responsible case manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
One out of eight resident records reviewed did not contain verification of a discharge
summary being completed.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 400.146 Immunizations.
(1) A resident shall have current immunizations as required by
the department of community health.
7

It is recommended that medical staff obtain a new MICR at time of placement,
review, administer any deficient immunizations as needed, and then sign the form.
R 400.147 Dental care.
(3) Reexamination shall be provided at least every 14 months
unless greater frequency is indicated.
It is recommended that updated dental exams be documented using the Dental
Screening form, rather than noted on a progress.
RFCJJ Contract: Residential Foster Care Juvenile Justice Program Types
Attachment A.2 Individual Therapy-Services-Mental Health and Behavior
Page 42 Stabilization Program
Individual therapy shall occur more than one time per week.
Two out of eight applicable case records reviewed did not have weekly individual
therapy occurring more than two times per week. Weekly individual therapy is noted
as occurring weekly in addition to group therapy.
RFCJJ Contact: Mental Health and Behavior Stabilization
Attachment A.2 Staffing Ratio
Page 42
The Contractor shall:
a. Provide a minimum of one on-duty direct childcare staff for
every five children during waking hours.
The facility’s current staff to resident ratio is two staff to ten residents. Staff can
supervise up to nine residents, before a second staff is required. Such practice
would violate DHHS contract requirements which does not appear to have occurred.
It is recommended that the facility stress with staff that the one to nine staff to
resident ratio does not include DHHS residents placed within the Mental Health
Behavior Stabilization program.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
8

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted five corrective action plans in the past year. The
07/06/2018 renewal inspection report resulted in a corrective action plan that
appropriately addressed the following as no repeat citations are noted to include: Out
of state records checks, and administrative case file audit occurring. Repeat citations
include personnel records including a job description, true copy of degree, annual
central registry checks occurring, performance evaluations, annual TB screening, use
of DHHS clothing inventory form, and the uploading of medical and dental
examinations into MiSACWIS. It is noted that the human resources department’s
structure drastically changed in the last year which attributes to several the personnel
deficiencies. It is recommended that the personnel departments corrective action
plan include establishing a mock personnel file, noting annual update time frames, as
to assist in possible future changes in the department.
SIR#2018C0219051 initiated on 05/18/2018 cited the facility for professional
boundaries in which a staff visited a discharged resident in another placement setting.
The corrective action plan included clinical staff reviewing and signing the
professional boundaries policy, along with the supervisor review any notifications of
staff contact with former residents on a monthly basis.
SIR#2018C0219061 initiated on 07/31/2018 cited the facility for behavior
management in which staff pulled a resident by his feet to his bedroom and placed on
an unwarranted seclusion. The corrective action plan included staff review of
behavior management techniques and appropriate use of seclusion, followed by staff
testing. The corrective action appears to have been successful as no repeat citations
have occurred.
SIR#2018C0219062 initiated on 07/30/2018 cited the facility for behavior
management regarding transport technique. The corrective action plan included
additional staff training on the primary restraint techniques transport. The corrective
action appears to have been successful as no repeat citations have occurred.
SIR#2019C0219006 initiated on 12/14/2018 cited the facility for staff qualifications
regarding antagonizing and flinging a resident to the floor for a minor infraction. The
corrective action plan included the termination of staff, retraining staff on child
protection, as well as revamping hiring questions.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
9

acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue their
regular license.
